messages: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:51): If I'm using lxml, how do I iterate over all h1, h2, and h3 elements?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:51): node.iter('h1') works, but node.iter('h1|h2') doesn't and I can't find any syntax that does
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:51): you could use xpath
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:52): (alhough it may not be the most efficient way and returns a lsit not an iterator)

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (17:52): "I very much hope we can (through W3C and MWI) drive user awareness of the mobile Web as a platform and start to create a mindset among developers and users that it's "OK" to have a different user experience between different devices / platforms - that this can be consistent with there being One Web." -- http://www.w3.org/QA/2008/11/_as_part_of_a.html
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (17:52): doesn't sound like One Web to me...
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (17:53): Different user experience as in different styling and device-specific widgets, or as in different pages entirely?
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (17:54): "'Full Web' to me is a code word for 'web pages designed exclusively for PCs.'" ouch, guess he never used a good mobile browser...
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:55): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Or I guess just do [x for x in node.iter() if x.tag in ('h1','h2', 'h3')]
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:55): (but that is kind of obvious)

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (17:57): this makes sense: "The idea is to allow the proxies to do their work on pages that have not taken mobile users into account, while stepping out of the way when a content provider has developer a service that adapts for mobile anyway."
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (17:57): such as webpages using HTML 4.01 Strict, with a handheld stylesheet, I assume (lol)
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (17:57): "I will say that the growth of flat-rate data plans is a positive trend in the industry right now and I hope that trend continues." me too!
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (17:59): "I sincerely hope the HTML Working Group considers our work in CDF before they re-invent the wheel." I hadn't heard of CDF before now...
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (18:02): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: CDF has been brought up many times in the SVG in HTML discussions, search public-html.
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (18:04): (though, not in a particularly compelling way...)
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (18:05): 78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9, CDF comes from here? http://www.w3.org/2004/CDF/
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:06): What's a good human readable and computer parsable biblio format?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:07): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Bibliography?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:07): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: yeah
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:07): bibtex is pretty standard for LaTeX applications
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:08): Dunno if it meets your needs
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:08): I just want something for Anolis that isn't Refer
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:08): And it needs to be easy to parse in Python :P

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (18:08): 78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9, this seems quite a stretch from the Mobile Web's Default Delivery Context: http://www.w3.org/TR/2007/CR-WICD-20070718/#child-objects
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (18:09): concludes CDF is FAIL.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:10): http://pybliographer.org/
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:10): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: Can you import a GPL module into a MIT licensed project?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:11): Incidentially I _really_ have no idea if bibtex is sutiable for what you want
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:11): BibTeX is suitable
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:11): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: IANAL
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:11): My IANAL opinion would be it is questionable
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:14): http://groups.google.com/group/comp.lang.python/browse_thread/thread/cd8646451aacfcc9
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:14): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, you can, but it means that any distribution that includes the GPL'd code is effectively licenced under the GPL
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:16): There appears to be other bibtex scripts in Python
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:16): like, MIT licensed ones
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:19): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: That sounds altogether like a better idea
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:21): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Where are the MIT licensed ones?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:22): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: http://code.google.com/p/bibstuff/ looks best
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (18:22): http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-faq.html#WhatDoesCompatMean
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:25): woah.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:26): The W3C doesn't have any exportable format of TRs, as far as I can see!
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:26): like, more than just http://www.w3.org/TR/
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:26): like, that I can use to build a bibtex file of all W3C TRs
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:29): http://www.w3.org/2002/01/tr-automation/tr.rdf
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:29): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: http://www.w3.org/2002/01/tr-automation/tr.rdf ?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:29): Oops, I lose
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:29): Where did you find any link to that!?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:30): http://google.com
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:30): and http://www.w3.org/2002/01/tr-automation/
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:30): (I searched for "w3c tr list")
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:30): In the <head> (I assumed that the W3C couldn't have a list without having accompnying RDF)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:31): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I failed to google for the right thing
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:31): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: So did I. Which was why I was amazed to not find it in two seconds.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:33): "Benefits of using Semantic Web technologies
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (18:34): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: view source on http://www.w3.org/TR/
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (18:34): There's a meta link
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (18:36): oh, that's probably what b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea was referring to.  nm.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:36): wonders how to efficiently implement keyframe-like animation in SVG, where each frame is 100KB of independently-generated SVG code and there's typically (but not always) a lot of similarity between adjacent frames
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:38): (In particular, animating http://philip.html5.org/misc/spec-links.html over the lifetime of the spec)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:52): problem: I can't include a converted copy of <http://www.w3.org/Style/Group/css3-src/biblio.ref> in Anolis, yet I need the same IDs to remain compat.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:54): Why can't you include that?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:54): licensing, etc.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:54): Why do you need the same IDs?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:54): compat. with existing documents
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:55): Are there practical compatibility considerations?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:55): seeming people like f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 want to use it for docs they already edit, yes
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:55): (i.e. do documents unavoidably rely on those specific IDs, or something?)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:55): The IDs isn't the problem.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:56): It's including everything in that file when it is rather long that is.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:56): It contains really random things.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:56): not that you can see that :)
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (19:04): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, maybe you could contact relevant staff at W3C about what you want?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:04): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: I don't really want to use Refer anyway, so it isn't particularly helpful
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:22): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: Also, I shouldn't have this document at all, so contacting the relevant staff may not be the best move :)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:25): But mentioning in public logged IRC that you have illicitly gained access to it is a good move? :-)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:25): :P
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:26): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I've implied often enough that I have got at the css3 postprocessor stuff :P
